head.title: Allergic to Fish? Avoid Air Around Them

hedline.hl1: Allergic to Fish? Avoid Air Around Them

abstract.p: Researchers find people who are allergic to fish can get reaction from inhaling allergens wafting off fish skin and should avoid fish markets; photo (S)

block.p: Most people who are allergic to pollen presumably make it a point to avoid blooming fields of ragweed or goldenrod.
But most people allergic to fish probably figure that to avoid an unpleasant reaction, they need only avoid eating anything that contains fish.
Most people who are allergic to pollen presumably make it a point to avoid blooming fields of ragweed or goldenrod.
But most people allergic to fish probably figure that to avoid an unpleasant reaction, they need only avoid eating anything that contains fish.

Researchers have found that for people allergic to fish, it is enough just to inhale some of the allergens wafting off the skin to have a reaction. And that, the study says, means that the piscatorial equivalent of the field in bloom is the fish market.

The report, published earlier this year in The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, was prepared by researchers from the Mayo Clinic in Rochester and researchers from a hospital in Madrid. Mayo researchers released details of the study this month.

The study was conducted at an open-air fish market in Madrid, where allergy patients have reported reactions. Hypersensitivity to fish is a significant problem in several European countries, the study said.
On 41 different days, researchers took air samples in the market, and they consistently found fish allergens.
